awd_abstract_narration:
The conference “From Subfactors to Quantum Topology” will be held in Geneva, Switzerland, June 27 - July 1, 2022. The topics will cover quantum invariants in low-dimensional topology, subfactor theory, and their connections to many branches of mathematics and theoretical physics. The conference will consist of talks by leading experts as well as early-career mathematicians. Many talks are survey talks directed to a wide audience and suitable for graduate students and young mathematicians. This award provides partial travel support to US-based mathematicians, particularly those in the early stages of their careers.
 
The conference will address topics on quantum invariants, topological quantum field theories, Khovanov and Heegaard Floer homology, the volume, AJ, slope, and knot-quiver conjectures, subfactors, and planar algebras,. It will provide a venue for sharing new results in the related fields; it will increase collaboration and communication among research experts globally; and it will introduce researchers, especially students and early career researchers, to important areas of current research. The conference website is
https://www.nccr-swissmap.ch/news-and-events/events/subfactors-quantum-topology-memory-vaughan-jones

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the grant is to support US based mathematicians to participate in the international conference "From Subfactors to Quantum Topology -- in memory of Vaughan Jones", which was held at the university of Geneva, Switzerland, June 27-July 1, 2022.  The PI is one of the co-organizers of the conference.

 The conference covers quantum invariants in low-dimensional topology, subfactor theory, and their connections to many branches of mathematics and theoretical physics, providing opportunities for cross-fertilization of ideas around these areas. The conference has 18 talks, given by world renown experts in the field. The speakers shared new results in the closely related fields of quantum topology, 3-manifold geometry and topology, and subfactor. It will increase collaboration and communication among research experts globally. The conference introduced researchers, especially students and early career researchers, to important problems and areas of current research, especially problems lying at the interface of quantum and classical topology in three dimensions.  Recordings of lectures of the conference are available publicly at the website of the conference.

Around 100 participants from all over the world, many women, many young mathematicians, and many graduate students took part in the conference. This grant supported travel expenses of 10 US based participants. 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/30/2023
Modified by: Thang Le
